reviewText: Firm Lower Body Sculpt 2 is the companion workout to Lower Body Sculpt 1.  Both of these workouts use the Firm Fanny Lifter, a high step with two parts, but whereas LBS1 consisted of all standing lower body work plus cardio, LBS2 has no cardio, and the entire workout is performed on the floor.  In addition, it alternates moves for the legs and butt with abs work.LBS2 is led by Libby Heath, a Firm instruction who usually has a background role as a modifier in Firm videos.  I found her to be more low-key than the typical Firm instructor, yet she was definitely competent and comfortable in the lead role.  In addition to the Fanny Lifter (FL), Libby suggests using one set of dumbbells ranging from 3-8 lbs, although you can also do the workout with no weights.  The 5-minute warm-up is the only part of the workout performed standing, and I found that it was a bit different from the Firm's usual, tired warm-ups and contained a few more unique moves, include several which more specifically targeted warming up the lower body.Following the warm-up, you first sit on the FL for a seated quad lift, holding the weight on the top of your thigh.  From there, you transition to hands-and-knees over the FL with the weight behind one knee for hamstring work, then return for another set of quad lifts, stretch, and repeat on the other side.  Moving to a lying position on the floor, Libby alternates sets of pelvic lifts with sets of abs crunches.Next comes inner and outer thigh work in a side-lying position; you are still using the weight here, this time holding it against your thigh. A final set of abs work follows this segment, this time focusing more on the obliques.  A 6-minute stretch concludes the workout and is performed mainly on the floor.  Libby does a good job of stretching the legs and including some nice twisting postures as well, bringing in the total time for the workout right around 34 minutes.Overall, I enjoyed this workout.  It is probably most appropriate for beginning to intermediate level exercisers.  Although I am a more advanced intermediate myself, I think this workout will work well for me if I use it as an add-on to a more intense workout; I also plan to experiment with varying the weights I use, perhaps adding ankle weights as well.
summary: Nice lower body workout, especially when used as an add-on
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video, led by Libby (the beginner modifier from BSS2 and BSS3), contains some innovative sitting and laying leg work, as well as some abdominal work. The equiptment it a tall box (any old 14 inch or so stool or chair would work) and some dumbells and ankle weights if you'd like. Starts with a warm up, then a stretch. Then you sit on the box and do some leg raises, then onto the floor, then bridge work, then abs.For me, this is a nice workout that leaves you feeling like you did something good for yourself, but not exhausted. It is a nice change of pace from my usual FIRM "diet" of lunges, squats, dips, and tall box climbs. I work this one in on short days by itself, with a cardio tape, or with "Upper Body Sculpt."
summary: Nice Change of Pace from Standing Leg Work
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you've done enough Firm workouts, you'll recognize the instructor as Libby, the Firm Master Instructor who is always performing the modifed version of exercises in other Firm workouts.  I wish they'd let Libby up front sooner, as I thought she did a great job.  She's got a lovely voice with a calm delivery providing good cues and tips, as well as coming across as friendly and encouraging.The workout itself is 30 minutes and uses the fanny lifter and light dumbells, as well as a floor mat.  After the warm-up, the remainder of the workout is done from either a seated position or on the floor.  I've done enough leg presses with the "signature fanny lifter" that the sight of it could make me cry - so if you're like me, take heart that this lower body workout has no leg presses (it's hard to believe, isn't it?).  In this workout, the fanny lifter is used to sit on, to lift your legs while in a prone position, to straddle or to lean your upper body over, but no leg presses.Overall, I love this workout and actually find it somewhat relaxing to do, which is not to say you won't feel it.  Some of the exercises have been seen in prior Firm workouts, but there are others I haven't seen elsewhere.There are a few minutes of ab work, but most of the workout focuses on exercises working on the legs and buns.  I believe this may be from the era of workouts that included Ab Sculpt, which is another one of my favorites.If you're looking for a lower body workout that is a departure from the norm and as pleasant and relaxing as it's possible for an exercise video to be, give this one a try.  This one makes me wish they'd set Libby free more often!
summary: Pleasant and Different Lower Body Workout
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 30 minute lower body workout is led by Libby Heath, who has been seen as the beginner modifier in many of the Firm workouts.  She is joined by 4 fellow Firm Master Instructors, this time Stephanie is the beginner modifier.  You will need one pair of weights for this workout (3-5 lbs) and the Fanny Lifter, if you do not have the Fanny Lifter a stool will work fine.  You can also do this workout without weights if you want.Following the warmup, you will work the lower body either seated or lying on the floor, no squats or leg presses here.  You start with seated quadricep work, lifting the knee then adding a leg extension, then you will move to the floor and work the same leg in a table position by doing hamstring work.  Then you return to seated position and do another set of quadricep work.  You repeat this entire sequence on the other leg.Next segment is done lying on the floor, starting with bridge work with weights.  The first set is done with feet on the floor, the second with your feet propped up on the Fanny Lifter or stool.  Then you will do some ab work with your feet still propped up including traditional crunches and oblique twists.  Then you will do one more set of bridge work, this time with some isolation work for each leg, first keeping the working leg on the  floor then the option of raising it up in the air.More ab work follows, this time reverse crunches and double crunches using some lower abs.  Then you will move to your side and do outer thigh work, leg lifts and shootouts.  Then staying on the same side you will work the inner thigh with leg lifts and sweeps.  Then you repeat on the opposite side.  Then you finish with more ab work this time focusing on the obliques before the final stretch.This is a nice workout for the lower body, but I found it to be pretty easy.  I would recommend this for beginner/intermediate levels only, advanced people will not find it challenging.  I thought that Libby did a very nice job instructing, she is encouraging and gives helpful hints.  Glad that she was able to get a lead for a change.  4 stars for this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am an "old-Firm" lover, pre-2000 videos being my first choice for working out. So I'll admit up front that I dislike the way this was designed- not too thrilled with the set or the way-too-low-key attitude. This was a part of a six-DVD set originally, designed really for beginner-to-intermediate exercisers, which came out as add-ons to The Firm Body Sculpt System 1 (Cardio Sculpt, Ab Sculpt and Body Sculpt). Libby is a nice enough instructor- nothing earth-shattering about her, but she's friendly and warm, obviously a Southerner based on her accent. The music the workout is synced to is soft in the background and is nothing memorable. The workout is challenging for a beginner to intermediate person. Just not exciting. It doesn't come close the original Lower Body Sculpting compilation, which came out in 1993, for intensity. That was more exciting and had better music (besides giving great results for the hips and things). This DVD is also not as good as Sculpted Buns, Hips and Thighs (which was actually heavy on the ab work). That featured the fabulous Tracey Long, and the music on that was AWESOME- tough moves, too, but not too tough. I'm not saying this doesn't get results- it probably would if you used it often enough. It's just so boring to me that I can't force myself to do that. Sorry, this isn't to put anyone down, it's just my opinion.There's a set of seated lifts for the front of the thighs, intersperced with some tablework for thee glutes. There's leg lifts and ab work, but it's all quite basic. For a true lower body (floorwork) challenge, I would suggest Vol.1 (especially), 2, 3 or 5 from the Classic Firms or the 2 DVD's I already listed.
summary: Nothing wrong with the workout, but not my fave
Title: N/A
